title: 107_hr4841
content: The Act may be cited as the "Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 400th Commemoration Commission Act of 2002". The Congress finds that the first European exploration of the Hudson River and Lake Champlain, as well as the introduction of steam navigation, were significant historical events leading to early contacts between Native Americans and Europeans in the New World. The establishment of Fort Orange and Dutch and English settlements in what is now the capital city of New York, along with French Quebec settlements as far south as Lake George, had a significant influence on American history, culture, law, commerce, and traditions of liberty. In 1807, Robert Fulton's steamboat CLERMONT successfully inaugurated steam navigation on the Hudson River, revolutionizing waterborne commerce in the United States. The National Park Service in New York owns resources related to the early history of the nation and the Hudson River Valley. In 2002, the State of New York established a Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commission. The purpose of this Act is to establish the Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 400th Commemoration Commission to ensure a suitable national observance of the Henry Hudson, Robert Fulton, and Samuel de Champlain 2009 anniversaries. The Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 2009 observances aim to provide a great visitor experience, recognize diverse communities, involve international participation, support marketing efforts, and promote heritage tourism and economic benefits in the United States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Commemoration" refers to honoring specific historic voyages. "Commission" refers to the Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 400th Commemoration Commission. "Governors" are the leaders of New York, New Jersey, and Vermont. "Secretary" is the head of the Interior department. "States" include New York, New Jersey, and Vermont. The term "States" in this Act refers to New York, New Jersey, and Vermont, including their agencies and entities. SEC. 4. HUDSON-FULTON-CHAMPLAIN 400TH COMMEMORATION COMMISSION. The "Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 400th Commemoration Commission" is established with 31 members appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from Governors, House of Representatives members, and Senators from specific regions. The "Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 400th Commemoration Commission" has members appointed by the Secretary, including Senators from New York, New Jersey, and Vermont, employees of the National Park Service, individuals knowledgeable of the Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area, and individuals with expertise relevant to the commemoration. The Commission members are appointed for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and meetings are held at least twice a year or as called by the Chairperson. The Commission members are appointed for life, vacancies are filled the same way, meetings are held at least twice a year or as called by the Chairperson. The Commission shall hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Voting requires a majority, and a quorum is a majority of the Commission. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are elected annually, with the Vice Chairperson serving in the Chairperson's absence. The Commission is responsible for planning and executing programs to commemorate historical voyages, coordinating activities nationwide, and collaborating with state and federal commemoration commissions. The Federal Government agencies and commemoration commissions, along with various organizations, are encouraged to organize anniversary activities to celebrate the voyages of Henry Hudson, Robert Fulton, and Samuel de Champlain. Technical assistance will be provided to states. The Commission will provide technical assistance to states, localities, and nonprofit organizations to further the commemoration of the voyages of Henry Hudson, Robert Fulton, and Samuel de Champlain. They will also coordinate scholarly research, publication, and interpretation of these voyages, ensuring a lasting legacy and public benefit through appropriate programs and facilities. The Commission will prepare a strategic plan and annual performance plans in accordance with federal regulations. The Commission, in accordance with federal regulations, will provide technical assistance and coordinate research on the voyages of Hudson, Fulton, and Champlain. They will prepare a strategic plan and annual performance plans. The Commission will submit a final report by September 30, 2010, containing a summary of activities, accounting of funds, and findings/recommendations. The Commission is empowered to disperse funds and accept donations. The Commission has the authority to disperse funds, accept donations, appoint advisory committees, authorize actions, procure supplies, and use the United States mails to carry out the Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 2009 commemoration. The Commission for the Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 2009 commemoration can use the United States mails, make grants to communities and organizations, and fund research on the early history of the voyages. Members of the Commission serve without compensation, except for Federal employees. Members of the Commission for the Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 2009 commemoration, who are Federal Government officers or employees, serve without additional compensation. They are allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties. The Chairperson can appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint and terminate an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission, and the Chairperson can set their compensation without regard to certain provisions of the United States Code. The executive director and personnel of the Commission have a maximum pay rate equivalent to level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail their personnel to assist the Commission in its duties. The Commission may accept personnel from States and use voluntary services. The Director of the National Park Service will provide support services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may procure temporary services as needed. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission's authority does not supersede that of the States or the National Park Service. The Commission will terminate on December 31, 2010.
